quoteLast: I left the Hotel St. Charles and took the ’bus for the Southern Pacific Station, which is a shabby, weatherworn wooden building down by the water side, in the French quarter of the city. A large, ill-kept waiting room was crowded with emigrants--chiefly “crackers” and “po’ white trash” from the cotton states.
title: On the Mexican Highlands, with a Passing Glimpse of Cuba
author: Edwards, William Seymour, 1856-1915

quoteFirst: A few minutes later the two cruisers altered course to port, as though to close the Kent at the entrance to the harbor. But at about this time it seems that the Invincible and Inflexible were seen over the land, and the enemy at once altered course, and increased speed to join their consorts. At
quoteLast: the squadron weighed anchor and proceeded out of the harbor, the Carnovan leading. On passing Cape Pembroke light, the five ships of the enemy appeared clearly in sight to the southeast, hull down.
title: History of the World War, Volume 2 (of 7)

quoteFirst: Robert McKinley told us that on May 16, 1952, approximately 25 gulls, probably glaucous gulls, arrived at the Arctic Research Laboratory and remained until May 25. On July 4, 1951, there, we recorded all gulls passing over the ice from 8:45 A.M. to
quoteLast: At this time the shore line and first 100 feet of water was free of ice; beyond, seaward, the ice was rough and dark for ¼ mile, succeeded by white ice for ¼ mile, next the high pressure ridge, and then open water of the Arctic Ocean.
title: Birds Found on the Arctic Slope of Northern Alaska

quoteFirst: I had been out last night, and Owen was going to-night, but I wanted to be doing something to occupy my thoughts. I knew I should not sleep. At
quoteLast: I sent word to Corporal Dyson, the wiring-corporal, to take his men up at eleven instead of ten, as the moon had not quite set. At eleven o’clock Owen and I were out in No Man’s Land putting out concertina wire between 80A and 81A bombing posts, which had recently been connected up by a deep narrow trench.
title:
Nothing of Importance
A record of eight months at the front with a Welsh battalion, October, 1915, to June, 1916

quoteLast: Mrs. Golden rose, indulged in a little kitten yawn behind her silvery hand, and said: "Well, I think I must be off to bed.... I find these May days so languid. Don't you, Mr. Babson? Spring fever. I just can't seem to get enough sleep....
title: The Job: An American Novel
